results.title: The Tree outside my house
results.brief_description:
The concept of the project was to represent the process of establishing data. The data was established as a set of 20 facts about the tree outside my house. The representations of the processes were to be strongly associated with my memories of learning and using these processes.
Initially the concept of the project only dealt with the
visualisation of the height of the tree and the process to
establish that fact. The visualisation of this process was to
be based on my childhood memories of a school activity.
The initial concept was later widened to include 20 facts
about the tree.
I was more interested in the processes used to establish
the facts than the facts themselves. I wanted to explore my memories and visually represent the process as a memory. The processes I wanted to represent were tied to the following facts:
•The name of the tree
•The botanical name of the tree
•The distance from the tree
•The angle to the top of the tree
•The height equals distance multiplied by pi
•The height of the tree
•The width of the trunk
•The volume of the tree
•The age of the tree
•The colour of the bark in RGB
•The colour of the bark in hexadecimal
•The bark’s range and difference of colours
•The shape of the leaves
•The colour of the leaves
•The size of the leaves
•The area of the leaves
•The noise of the wind in the leaves of the tree
•The number of branches
•The location of the tree

results.title: The Tree of wooden clogs = L'albero degli zoccoli
results.creator_credit: Ermanno Olmi, GPC, Ital-Noleggio Cinematografico and Radiotelevisione Italiana
results.brief_description: Scenes from the lives of three peasant families, living in the same farmhouse in Lombardy at the end of the nineteenth century, are chronicled over the course of a year. Their struggles to survive are slowly revealed in a mosaic of small, but detailed incidents which poignantly capture the repetitive drudgery and occasional joys of the exploited peasant class in rural Italy. Following the tradition of Italian neo-realist cinema, Olmi drew on a large ensemble cast of non-professional actors and shot the film on 16mm in a lyrical documentary style. The muted colour and straight-on, eye-level cinematography captures the striking beauty of the Italian countryside through the seasons without diminishing or romanticising the lives of the peasants who work it. In Italian with English subtitles.

results.title: The tree of truth
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Davidson Films
results.brief_description:
The story of a land with a magic tree that provides true or false answers to any problem posed. The king poses a question about wealth - experts disagree as to whether it is an addition or a sub-traction problem, although the tree maintains both methods are acceptable.
Previewing is essential. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: The Tree of life
results.creator_credit: Gerard De Boe, Harold Cooper and Lintas Film Unit
results.brief_description: The discovery, harvesting and preparation of palm oil in the Belgian Congo. Something of the history of the industry, the concession given to Lever Bros by King Leopold and the transportation difficulties in penetrating the interior of the Congo are shown.

results.title: The Tree house
results.brief_description: Asks if man can live in the world without oblierating its beauty. Shows how a bulldozer driver befriends a young boy who has built a treehouse on the edge of a site the man has to clear. Ends with the driver unable to tell the boy why his tree has to come down.

results.title: The Tree
results.creator_credit: Georg Schimanski and International Council for Education Media
results.brief_description: Time-lapse photography helps us appreciate the marvellous seasonal changes undergone by a large oak tree. These changes also affect the many animals and insects that feed and live in the tree. Among other things, the film describes how the tree nourishes itself during the growing season, how it synthesizes various elements during the day and at night. The tree and the creatures who inhabit it form an impressive microcosm, kept in good health by natural checks and balances.

results.title: The Treasure of Sierra Madre
results.creator_credit: John Huston, Henry Blanke and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: John Huston won Academy Awards both as director and writer of this film. Based on B. Traven’s novel, it reveals the effects of greed and the lure of sudden wealth on three penniless prospectors. Humphrey Bogart, as Fred C. Dobbs, gives one of the best performances of his career. We watch him change from a likeable drifter into a man capable of killing his best friend in cold blood.

results.title: The Travelling tune: a musical phantasy in paper
results.brief_description: A round the world journey in which we see American jazz trumpeters, Venetian goldoliers, Mexican cowboys, Amerstdam canal-side houses, New York skyscrpaers and Bavarian beer mugs. All these scenes are created from colorful paper cutouts.

results.title: The Travelling players = O Thiassos [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Theo Angelopoulos, Giorgos Samiotis and Papalios Productions
results.brief_description: With the release of “The Travelling players” in 1975, Theo Angelopoulos cemented a reputation as one of the leading filmmakers of his generation. Released just after the collapse of the fascist military junta, the film’s international critical success led to a short-lived Renaissance for Greek language cinema. Angelopoulos’s mise-en-scene for “The Travelling players” involves complicated long takes, a concentrated editing and shooting of scenes that allows for the distillation of time and space that is comparable to Tarkosvsky, Welles and Visconti. In “The Travelling players” a small group of thespians travel through Greece performing plays based on Greek history and myth. They become our witness to the modern history of Greece as they take us through the fall of the Ottoman Empire, the tragedies of the two World Wars, the calamities of the Civil War and the resulting political oppression culminating in the establishment of the Junta in 1966 by the Greek military. The “players” find themselves moving across the stage of history itself, and caught in the modern human dilemma of wishing to escape history and consciousness but never able to do so. The film also becomes a mythic investigation of fascism and its destructiveness, and also a passionate, if pessimistic, cry for truth and liberation, that itself echoes with the poisoned chalice of Greece’s democratic history. Angelopoulos makes no concessions to notions of populist or commercially based cinema. “The Travelling players” assumes knowledge of Greek history, both ancient and modern, as well as assuming that it is viewed by a literate audience familiar with modernist conceptions of philosophical and political engagement. For some audiences, “The Travelling players” might be read as elitist and obscure. But for those who decide to commit and engage with the film, its formal experimentations and intellectual concerns, they may find it one of the astounding cinematic experiences. Winner of the Palme d’Or at Cannes. In Greek with English subtitles.

results.title: The Travelling divorcees
results.creator_credit: Michelle Rayner, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Michelle Rayner reflects on the evolution of the marriage between Patricia and Michael, her parents. Throughout the years they have gone through many changes both personally and as a couple, and often reflecting the times.
